content.description:
This was my first desert tower. We rolled up at the base in early March 1987 thinking that this was still unclimbed. There was no guidebook, no info. Alas, we spotted slings on the obvious sunny South Face route. Â So we climbed what looked to be the second-best line on the formation, the semi-analog crack on the backside. This turned out to be a not-so-good route. But a cool summit! Three pitches.

1. Begin up a 5.4 crack that works up and right to a crack/flake system.

2. Follow this flake system past loose blocks (the "milkcrates") and a bolt to a stance at a major bedding seam. A3

3. The top pitch takes a nice right-facing dihedral. It's maybe A3- very briefly past a big loose block then easier.
content.protection: A couple sets of cams, a smallish selection of pitons from Lost Arrows to Angles.
content.location: This is on the northeast side of the formation. Sort of the analog crack to the original route, but perhaps a bit more left of center. The top pitch follows a crack in a prominent right-facing dihedral. Start under this right-facing dihedral.

content.description:
Cool thin line up the shady side of Eagle Plume.

First pitch is the crux with choss at the bottom and thin stuff up high as you traverse left.

This pitch was previously climbed.

Fun little route and easy hike.
content.protection: Triple rack of cams, some big Peckers and some thin Lost Arrows. Couple bolts here and there to link up seams. As I recall we didn't need anything really wide (#5, #6). All bolts have hangers (I think).
content.location:
Thin crack line left of Milk Crates From Hell. First pitch climbed previously as evidenced by fixed RURP and old fixed Birdbeak.

Rap route.

climbs.name: Eagle Feather (a.k.a. South Face)
climbs.fa: Bill Forrest, Frank Luptom, 1976  FFA- Craig Kenyon, Jeff Cristol, 1989

content.description:
Pitch 1: Begin up a loose 5.8 crack, then a 5.7 off-width to a large ledge.

Pitch 2: Climb broken rock to a small ledge at the base of a small, clean, tight dihedral. Climb the dihedral then traverse a few feet right to a thin crack(blue alien), that guards the anchors.(5.10)

Pitch 3:Climb up some loose rock in the right crack to a dihedral ramp with fun jamming.  Then climb up a loose bedding seam to a pin and traverse left to a belay on top of the seam. This is the best pitch on the route.(5.10)

Pitch 4:Climb clean dihedral above to the summit.(5.9)

Descent:Rappel the route.  Desert Rock IV says you can also rappel LOLA.
content.location: The route is obviously on the south side.  Eagle Feather climbs up the middle of the face.  The first pitch starts a little to the right of center.
